div1.p: I'm glad that personal stuff I sent you will run. Fortunately, the "dear Public" seems capable of swallowing any amount of the same hash. The books, also, have been sent you and the photographs will come.

Nevertheless I'm regretting that you have seen fit to turn aside from your own poetic work to these articles — though the gods honor that authoritative criticism of poetry is needed here in America. Keep singing! We can't spare you: unless necessity says as much

Yes, Sterling is a good chap. And in his poem "The Testimony of the Suns" has done some of the finest,
22
itillon imagination I know. I'm angry with the diffen heavens for not having worked more passionately to make his last two books nearer the value of the first. Yet how can I be angry when one who has done such splendid work writes me thatmodestly in sending his books that he does not regard himself as "in the same class with me." Only a very good chap would do that.

As for his "materialism", which he has mentioned to you, it comes from ten things. From having, I suspect, been taught the artfulness of the harness too soon — by an astronomy-loving father; and from a certain wrong paganism that is rampant on the crant theme: the "eat, drink, and be merry, for tomorrow we die" sort, not the best Greek

kind that delights in life and the beauty of it, with death, which is to be met gloriously, powerless to awe the spirit to despair, whatever it may be.

But these things can be better said than written. So can't you come down here and visit me some daysomeday — with Mrs. Neihardt, who, if two poets would be too much with for her, might take refuge with Mrs. Rice? Off I'm off in August, to be in the country again in January; but at any other time you are passing this way, or can do so, we'll be glad to see you.
